awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Labor Dynamics, Migration, and Intergenerational Community Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
How do social and historical factors direct migration? This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of rigorous, empirical data collection and analysis, explores how migrants form and sustain communities through histories of connected movement. In tracking a South-South migration route, the researcher aims to ascertain the historical processes by which migrants are channeled into specific forms of labor in different places. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in scientific methods of rigorous data collection and analysis, the project would improve scientific understanding by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations invested in formulating best practices for effective and sustainable migration policies.

Anna Reumert, under the supervision of Dr. Naor Ben-Yehoyada of Columbia University will explore what factors influence the integration or marginalization of migrant workers across an understudied migration route in the Global South. Through fieldwork with an intergenerational Sudanese migrant community in Lebanon, the project explores the processes by which identities are formed, negotiated and contested through histories of migration. The project asks what new information the experiences of this migrant population can reveal about age, gender, ethnic, and other forms of cultural identity and hierarchy. The researcher will employ a range of ethnographic data collection and analytical methods such observational research at cultural sites, interviews with migrant workers, focus groups, and life histories, to map intergenerational communal networks. The project advances anthropological and other social scientific theory related to migration and labor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Phase 1: August 2019-March 2020, Beirut 

In the first phase of the research, I conducted on-site fieldwork, specifically ethnographic participation and informal interviews, with Sudanese migrant communities across three sites: The Sudanese Club, the Migrant Community Center, and a Sudanese-owned cafe in a southern part of Beirut. I taught volunteer English classes every week night for migrant women and men at the Sudanese Club and the Migrant Community Center during this phase. In addition, I visited my interlocutors at home and, in some cases, at their workplaces, and I met with interlocutors at other establishments popular to Sudanese communal life in Beirut, including cafes and barbershops. 

Phase 2: March 2020-December 2020, remote research

During the 2020 covid-19 lockdown of Lebanon, I shifted my research to remote, as per my university’s instructions. I stayed active with my interlocutors through daily Whatsapp calls, and held classes remotely with my students. I also took part in monitoring migrant needs for food and housing, including by interviewing migrants about housing evictions in Beirut.

Phase 3: January 2021-July 20221, Beirut 

I returned to Beirut when the university permitted international research. During this phase, I met with my interlocutors for follow-up interviews. I updated my research methodology to fit the health guidance and restrictions in place at the time; only meeting outdoors, masked and not sharing meals. 

 

Outcomes

I have written five dissertation chapter drafts based on this research, and am at the final stage of dissertation writing. I have published and presented my research publicly, including:

Publications

“Good Guys, Mad City: Etiquettes of Migration Among Sudanese Men in Beirut””, Mashriq&Mahjar, July 2020. 

Conference presentations

“After Labor: Migrant Workers in Lebanon’s Crisis”, the Arab Council for the Social Sciences 2021 Conference "Interrogating the Social Sciences in the Vortex of Crises: Waves of Discontent and Demands for Change", Beirut, December 10 2021.

“Sanduk as Survival”, panel: “Patronage and Dependency in Islamic Ethics and Economies of Care: Ethnographic Inquiries from Africa and the Middle East”, American Anthropological Association-Baltimore, November 18 2021.

“Migrants and Workers: Sudanese Labor Struggles in Beirut”, Khayrallah Center for Lebanese Diaspora Studies: New Perspectives on Middle East Migrations Conference, August 24-26 2021.

“On the Run and Out of Place”, Seminar presentation at the Institute for Research on Women and Gender Studies (Columbia), May 7 2021.

“The Custodians of Beirut”, Seminar presentation at the OIB-Beirut, December 3 2020.

​​“Wither the Migrant Worker in Lebanon’s Crisis?”, panel: Black and Arab Across the Red Sea, Middle East Studies Annual Meeting, October 2020; panelist and panel co-chair.

Interviews

“Anna Reumert Author Interview”, Khayrallah Center , September 28 2021, https://lebanesestudies.ojs.chass.ncsu.edu/index.php/mashriq/announcement/view/28

Findings

The big unforeseen event during my research was the Lebanese popular uprising against the banking crisis that began on October 19 and led to a month-long general strike, during which much of the country was effectively shut down, while the streets opened up to new practices of public and communal life. Migrant workers were largely excluded from this new form of life and the active citizenry it produced. The question of what kind of political subject the migrant worker is, or can be, in a country like Lebanon, became central to my research because of this.

My interlocutors, with whom I watched the uprising from the streets and on TV at their homes, expressed that they did not feel welcome at the protest and, because they are legally excluded from unionizing and not protected by Lebanese labor laws, could not participate in the general strike even if they wanted to. Many therefore viewed the uprising largely as an obstacle for their livelihood as migrants in Beirut, as the roadblocks prevented them from getting to work, while employers who lost profit would use the strike as an excuse to fire or underpay migrant workers. What is more, the Migrant Community Center, which had been a central safespace for my interlocutors and for migrants across Lebanon, closed during the entirety of the uprising, since the Lebanese employees at the center joined the general strike. The loss of this space led many migrant workers to build their own emergency networks of material support and care, including by establishing mutual aid funds and co-habitating with many migrants sharing a household to save their vanishing funds. I was invited into these spaces and networks of support, and documented their efforts of co-survival and forms of “kin-making”.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2021
Modified by: Anna S Reumert

Image
  • Co-PI during research in Lebanon
    Jenny Gustafsson
    Anna S Reumert
    Anna Simone Reumert
